title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam?
What was the name of the first caliph after Muhammad's death?
Which dynasty came to power after the assassination of the fourth caliph, Ali?
What was the name of the city built by the Abbasid Family as their new capital?
What was the result of the Mongols' approach to Baghdad in 1258 CE?
Why did local leaders throughout the empire refuse to pay taxes?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were satisfied with Umayyad rule

options.label: C
options.text: Because they spent the money on their own courts instead

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were ignorant of the caliph's rule

multiple-choice.question: What was the legacy of the Islamic Empire?

options.label: C
options.text: A lasting mark on the world through written and spoken Arabic, Islam, and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals

options.label: D
options.text: A decline in trade and commerce

multiple-choice.question: Who were the Abbasid Family?

options.label: A
options.text: A rival clan of the Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: B
options.text: A direct descendants of the prophet Muhammad

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Umayyads' stabilization of the empire?

options.label: C
options.text: The empire was stabilized by replacing the ruling elite in conquered territories with Muslim officials and allowing local customs to continue

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of the decadent displays of wealth in the Abbasid caliphate?

options.label: A
options.text: The caliph's dependence on his entourage

options.label: D
options.text: The local leaders' refusal to pay taxes

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What was altered in the painting "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid" to make it more suitable for Victorian England?

options.label: B
options.text: To remove parts that were deemed too risqué for Victorian England

options.label: C

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Roman conquest of the Iberian Peninsula in the 3rd century?

options.label: B
options.text: The spread of Latin throughout the region

options.label: C
options.text: The adoption of Arabic as the official language

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of modern Spanish comes from Latin?
Which of the following languages contributed to the development of modern Spanish?
In what year did the Catholic Church consolidate its power and adopt Castellano as the official state language?
What was the result of the Spanish conquest of the Americas?
Which language had an influence on Spanish in the 18th century?
What was the result of people in Central and South America revolting to gain independence from Spain in the 19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The adoption of Spanish as the official language

multiple-choice.question: How many countries and Puerto Rico have Spanish as their official language?
What is the approximate number of inhabitants of Hispanic America?
What is the reason for Spanish retaining its unity of syntax, grammar, and vocabulary despite its widespread use?

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that although a person in Buenos Aires might use words that aren’t fully intelligible to someone in Bogotá or Mexico City, Spanish retains enough unity to remain one language.

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What was the first ever touchscreen used for?

options.label: A
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers update weather forecasts

options.label: B
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers update flight plans

options.label: C
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers manage airport schedules

options.label: D
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers communicate with pilots

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary limitation of the first touchscreen?
What type of touchscreen is favored for industrial or mass use?
What is the primary advantage of capacitive touchscreens?
What is the reason why your body is a good conductor?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is made up of 100% water

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is made up of 60% water

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is made up of 80% water

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is made up of 90% water

What type of objects can activate the screen?

options.label: C
options.text: Objects that conduct electricity about as well as your finger

options.label: D
options.text: Objects that are made of metal

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the nodes in a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To interact with the existing electric field

options.label: D
options.text: To induce a weak electric current

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you click on an app on a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: C
options.text: Your finger functions like a third electrical line

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is worm grunting, also known as worm charming or fiddling?

options.label: A
options.text: A traditional practice that involves making a loud, deep croaking noise to summon worms

options.label: B
options.text: A method of hunting worms using a fork and stick

options.label: C
options.text: A type of earthworm species found in the Florida Panhandle

options.label: D
options.text: A behavior exhibited by moles to catch worms

multiple-choice.question: What was the most popular hypothesis proposed to explain why worms would surface despite being vulnerable to predators?

options.label: A
options.text: That worms were charmed by the noise

options.label: B
options.text: That worm grunting tickled the worms' bodies

options.label: C
options.text: That worm grunting mimicked falling rain

options.label: D
options.text: That worms fled because they believed they were being pursued by moles

multiple-choice.question: Who tested the hypothesis proposed by Charles Darwin that worms might flee from the ground when it trembled because they believed they were being pursued by moles?

options.label: C
options.text: A British girl who set the world record for "most worms charmed"

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Catania's experiment when he released a single mole into worm- and soil-filled arenas?

options.label: A
options.text: About 10% of the worms crawled to the surface in the first hour

options.label: B
options.text: About 30% of the worms crawled to the surface in the first hour

options.label: C
options.text: About 50% of the worms crawled to the surface in the first hour

options.label: D
options.text: About 70% of the worms crawled to the surface in the first hour

multiple-choice.question: Why does the behavior of worms persist despite being vulnerable to predators?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a more frequent predator

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a rarer predators

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is beneficial for a predator species to maintain its adaptations against prey

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is beneficial for a species to maintain its adaptations against any predator

multiple-choice.question: Who set the world record for "most worms charmed"?
What was the method used by the 10-year-old British girl to charm the worms?

options.label: A
options.text: She made a loud, deep croaking noise using a metal strip and wooden stake

options.label: B
options.text: She wiggled a fork in the ground and hit it with a stick

options.label: C
options.text: She used a mole to dig up the worms

options.label: D
options.text: She used a herring gull to dig up the worms

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the experiment when Catania recorded the vibrations produced by worm grunters and moles digging?

options.label: B
options.text: The frequencies did not overlap at all

multiple-choice.question: Why did Charles Darwin propose that worms might flee from the ground when it trembled?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he believed they were being pursued by moles

options.label: B
options.text: Because he believed they were being pursued by herring gulls

options.label: C
options.text: Because he believed they were being pursued by wood turtles

options.label: D
options.text: Because he believed they were being pursued by other earthworms

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the discovery that earthworms have evolved a behavior to escape a top predator, the mole?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that earthworms are more vulnerable to predators

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that earthworms are more adaptable to predators

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that earthworms have evolved a behavior to escape a top predator

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that earthworms have evolved a behavior to attract a top predator

options.label: B

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of existential risk?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of extinction or the unrecoverable collapse of human civilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated rate of natural existential risk per century?
What is the potential consequence of a global nuclear war?
What is the potential consequence of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: A few degrees Celsius of warming

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential risk of engineered pandemics?
What is the potential risk of unaligned AI?

options.label: A
options.text: An existential risk if it is not perfectly aligned with human values

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated rate of anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?

options.label: B
options.text: The same as the background rate

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential consequence of unaligned AI?
What is the potential consequence of engineered pandemics?
What is the potential consequence of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: A few degrees Celsius of warming

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of Lactobacilli in the vagina?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce an acid that raises the vagina's pH

options.label: B
options.text: To produce an acid that lowers the vagina's pH

options.label: C
options.text: To produce enzymes that degrade epithelial cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the species of yeast that is the usual culprit of vaginal thrush or yeast infections?
What happens when the balance within the vagina is disrupted, allowing Candida albicans to assume its disease-causing forms?

options.label: C
options.text: Candida albicans multiplies and secretes enzymes that degrade epithelial cells

multiple-choice.question: What can make people more susceptible to vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: C
options.text: Antibiotic treatments, lower immunity, hormonal changes, diet, and certain lifestyle habits

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of recurrent vaginal yeast infections in some people?

options.label: C
options.text: Harmless yeasts used in brewing and baking

What is the primary reason for the lack of research on the vaginal microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: A better understanding of the subject

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in the incidence of vaginal yeast infections

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in the incidence of vaginal yeast infections

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What is the main defense mechanism of the hagfish?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to produce a loud noise

multiple-choice.question: How does the hagfish use its slime to escape from predators?

options.label: B
options.text: By producing a loud noise to scare the predator away

options.label: C
options.text: By lodging the slime in the predator's gills and escaping

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as a measure of a country's well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It only accounts for the monetary value of goods and services produced and sold on the market.

options.label: B
options.text: It takes into account the distribution of wealth among the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It considers the value of non-market activities such as public services.

options.label: D
options.text: It estimates overall well-being based on health and education.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the alternative metric introduced in the 1970s as a measure of a country's well-being?
Which country is an example of a country that has successfully balanced economic growth with environmental sustainability and improved living standards?
What is the main advantage of a dashboard approach to measuring a country's well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a single number that captures the full picture of a country's well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: It considers multiple factors such as GDP, HDI, and SDI.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a simple and easy-to-understand approach.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a complex and difficult-to-understand approach.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the metric that takes into account health and education, as well as income per capita to estimate overall well-being?
Who introduced the idea of Gross National Happiness (GNH) as an alternative metric to GDP?

options.label: A
options.text: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk of Bhutan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of the Sustainable Development Index (SDI)?

options.label: A
options.text: It only accounts for economic growth.

options.label: B
options.text: It only accounts for environmental sustainability.

options.label: D
options.text: It takes into account both well-being and environmental sustainability.

multiple-choice.question: Which country has made notable progress in balancing economic growth with environmental sustainability and improved living standards?
What is the main advantage of the Human Development Index (HDI)?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a single number that captures the full picture of a country's well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: It considers multiple factors such as health, education, and income per capita.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a simple and easy-to-understand approach.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a complex and difficult-to-understand approach.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of the Gross National Happiness (GNH)?

options.label: A
options.text: It only accounts for economic growth.

options.label: B
options.text: It only accounts for environmental sustainability.

options.label: D
options.text: It takes into account both well-being and environmental sustainability.

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the decrease in oxygen levels at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: The air pressure decreases, and the relative amounts of each compound remain the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The air pressure increases, and the relative amounts of each compound remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: The air pressure decreases, and the relative amounts of each compound change.

options.label: D
options.text: The air pressure increases, and the relative amounts of each compound change.

multiple-choice.question: What triggers the body's response to the decrease in oxygen levels?
What is the primary adaptation of the body to high altitudes in the short term?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the concentration of hemoglobin in the blood

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the volume of plasma in the blood

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the volume of plasma in the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when the body's breathing rate increases in response to high altitudes?
What are the two life-threatening conditions that can occur at high altitudes?
What is the primary advantage of living at high altitude for some people?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen levels in the air

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic advantages that can prevent minor altitude sickness

options.label: D
options.text: Increased volume of plasma in the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary risk of climbing to extremely high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen levels in the air

options.label: C
options.text: Life-threatening conditions such as HACE and HAPE

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased oxygen levels in the air

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary adaptation of the body to high altitudes in the long term?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the concentration of hemoglobin in the blood

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the volume of plasma in the blood

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the volume of plasma in the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when the body's breathing rate increases in response to high altitudes over a longer period?
What is the result of the increased pressure in the blood vessels at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen levels in the air

options.label: C
options.text: Fluid buildup in the brain and lungs

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased oxygen levels in the air

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the British Museum's collection of cultural artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: The museum has too few artifacts.

options.label: B
options.text: The museum has too many artifacts.

options.label: C
options.text: Nearly half of the museum's most notable pieces have disputed ownership.

options.label: D
options.text: The museum does not have any artifacts from the 17th century.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the disputed ownership of the Benin Bronzes?

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum acquired them through a trade deal.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum acquired them after the Benin Punitive Expedition in 1897.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin Royal Family donated them to the British Museum.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin Bronzes were always owned by the British Museum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum's stance on returning cultural artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: The museum returns all artifacts that are requested.

options.label: B
options.text: The museum does not return objects but lends them widely.

options.label: C
options.text: The museum only returns artifacts that are deemed to be of cultural significance.

options.label: D
options.text: The museum does not return any artifacts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the legacy of colonialism in relation to cultural artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legacy of cultural exchange and sharing.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a legacy of centuries of colonial power that repeats itself again and again with different artifacts in different museums.

options.label: C
options.text: C: It is a legacy of cultural suppression and erasure.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a legacy of cultural preservation and protection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Benin Dialogue Group?

options.label: A
options.text: To discuss potential solutions for the return of the Benin Bronzes.

options.label: B
options.text: To acquire more cultural artifacts for the British Museum.

options.label: C
options.text: To suppress the cultural identity of the Benin people.

options.label: D
options.text: To erase the history of the Benin Kingdom.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why parrots are able to mimic human speech?

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to mimic human speech
